overview.short: Haemophilus ducreyi is a fastidious Gram-negative short rod associated with chancroid, a sexually transmitted genital ulcer disease.
overview.clinical_context: Primarily linked to painful genital ulcers and regional lymphadenitis; culture is challenging and NAAT is often preferred where available.

species_markers.notes: Strongest practical discriminator; H. ducreyi is classically associated with chancroid.
Supports separation from some other Haemophilus species that are more often catalase positive.
Helps distinguish from certain respiratory Haemophilus species that more commonly reduce nitrate.

common_confusions.reason: Other Haemophilus species can appear similar in basic morphology but differ in clinical context and factor requirements.
Pasteurellaceae overlap; fastidious growth on enriched media can resemble Haemophilus.

when_to_question_identification: Respiratory-source isolate argues against H. ducreyi (typically mucosal/ulcer-associated).
Clear X+V factor profile consistent with H. influenzae/parainfluenzae may indicate a different species.
Good growth on MacConkey Agar argues against H. ducreyi (fastidious, typically inhibited).

recommended_next_tests.test: X and V factor requirement (hemin and NAD)
recommended_next_tests.reason: Helps confirm Haemophilus biology and distinguish related species.
Strong option for confirming species when culture is obtained.
Often preferred due to culture difficulty in routine labs.
